issues.description: The solution implementation declares attributes using snake_case names (e.g. lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students) but all constructor parameters, getters/setters, and other methods use camelCase field names (e.g. lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents). This name mismatch makes the solution class internally inconsistent and will cause compilation errors (undefined symbols) and confusion for students who expect the attributes named as in the UML/problem statement (camelCase). The problem statement and UML show camelCase attribute names, the template expects students to add those attributes, but the solution uses different attribute identifiers.
issues.suggested_fix: Make attribute identifiers consistent with the UML/problem statement and with the rest of the class. For example, in solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java rename the declared fields to camelCase (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors) or alternatively update all uses (constructor, getters/setters, methods) to refer to the declared snake_case fields. Aligning names will remove compilation errors and match the expected design described in the problem statement.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and attribute list) specifies attribute names using camelCase (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors). In the solution implementation the fields are declared using snake_case (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, number_of_guest_students, number_of_lecturers, number_of_tutors) while the constructor and methods in the solution refer to the camelCase identifiers (e.g., this.lectureName). This creates a naming mismatch between the problem specification and the solution and also an internal inconsistency in the solution code. Students following the UML will expect camelCase fields in the template; seeing different names in the solution (and references to identifiers that do not match the declared fields) increases cognitive load and may lead to confusion and compile/runtime errors when comparing their implementation to the reference.
issues.suggested_fix: Use consistent camelCase attribute names to match the UML and expected template naming. Rename the solution fields to: lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors, and ensure all constructor assignments and method references use these same identifiers. Alternatively (less desirable), update the problem statement/UML to explicitly use snake_case, but aligning the solution to the UML/camelCase convention is recommended to avoid student confusion.
